reports.description:
The number of ghost windows present (the number of nodes underneath explicit/window-objects/top(none)/ghost, modulo race conditions).  A ghost window is not shown in any tab, does not share a domain with any non-detached windows, and has met these criteria for at least memory.ghost_window_timeout_seconds, or has survived a round of about:memory's minimize memory usage button.

Ghost windows can happen legitimately, but they are often indicative of leaks in the browser or add-ons.

The number of ghost windows present (the number of nodes underneath explicit/window-objects/top(none)/ghost, modulo race conditions).  A ghost window is not shown in any tab, does not share a domain with any non-detached windows, and has met these criteria for at least memory.ghost_window_timeout_seconds, or has survived a round of about:memory's minimize memory usage button.

Ghost windows can happen legitimately, but they are often indicative of leaks in the browser or add-ons.
description for vsize-max-contiguous...
description for vsize-max-contiguous...
Scope information for scripts.

The number of ghost windows present (the number of nodes underneath explicit/window-objects/top(none)/ghost, modulo race conditions).  A ghost window is not shown in any tab, does not share a domain with any non-detached windows, and has met these criteria for at least memory.ghost_window_timeout_seconds, or has survived a round of about:memory's minimize memory usage button.

Ghost windows can happen legitimately, but they are often indicative of leaks in the browser or add-ons.
The same as 'heap-committed/allocated'.

Memory mapped by the process that is present in physical memory, also known as the resident set size (RSS).  This is the best single figure to use when considering the memory resources used by the process, but it depends both on other processes being run and details of the OS kernel and so is best used for comparing the memory usage of a single process at different points in time.
Memory used for storing GL textures.
The number of host objects stored for access via URLs (e.g. blobs passed to URL.createObjectURL).
Unused bytes due to fragmentation in the bins used for 'small' (<= 2 KiB) allocations. These bytes will be used if additional allocations occur.
Memory used by the event targets table in a window's DOM, and the objects it points to, which include XHRs.
Committed bytes which the heap allocator uses for internal data structures.
The same as 'heap-committed/allocated'.

Memory mapped by the process that is present in physical memory, also known as the resident set size (RSS).  This is the best single figure to use when considering the memory resources used by the process, but it depends both on other processes being run and details of the OS kernel and so is best used for comparing the memory usage of a single process at different points in time.

Memory mapped by the process that is present in physical memory and not shared with any other processes.  This is also known as the process's unique set size (USS).  This is the amount of RAM we'd expect to be freed if we closed this process.

Memory mapped by the process that is present in physical memory and not shared with any other processes.  This is also known as the process's unique set size (USS).  This is the amount of RAM we'd expect to be freed if we closed this process.

Memory used by the system allocator that is currently allocated to the application. This is distinct from the jemalloc heap that Firefox uses for most or all of its heap allocations. Ideally this number is zero, but on some platforms we cannot force every heap allocation through jemalloc.

Memory used by the system allocator that is currently allocated to the application. This is distinct from the jemalloc heap that Firefox uses for most or all of its heap allocations. Ideally this number is zero, but on some platforms we cannot force every heap allocation through jemalloc.

Memory mapped by the process, including code and data segments, the heap, thread stacks, memory explicitly mapped by the process via mmap and similar operations, and memory shared with other processes. This is the vsize figure as reported by 'top' and 'ps'.  This figure is of limited use on Mac, where processes share huge amounts of memory with one another.  But even on other operating systems, 'resident' is a much better measure of the memory resources used by the process.

Memory mapped by the process, including code and data segments, the heap, thread stacks, memory explicitly mapped by the process via mmap and similar operations, and memory shared with other processes. This is the vsize figure as reported by 'top' and 'ps'.  This figure is of limited use on Mac, where processes share huge amounts of memory with one another.  But even on other operating systems, 'resident' is a much better measure of the memory resources used by the process.
Objects, including fixed slots.
Non-fixed object slots.
Normal (non-asm.js) indexed elements.
Miscellaneous object data.
Shapes in a property tree.
Shapes in dictionary mode.
Decoded image data which is stored on the heap.
Raster image source data and vector image documents.
Decoded image data which is stored on the heap.
Raster image source data and vector image documents.
Memory used by gfx surface of the given type.
GC arenas in non-empty chunks that is decommitted, i.e. it takes up address space but no physical memory or swap space.
